dib/ironic-python-agent-ramdisk/install..message: Let us actually stop upgrading pip for Python 3. We haven't used new features for a while.
now you don't need this variable at all

I was actually looking at what's happening in the ubuntu bionic job (that uses Python 3), we might need to upgrade something there too. The pip version installed by default is very old (9.0.1), and the job is exiting with the error:
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'wheel'
This includes CentOS 8, let's actually check for 3.6.9 then?

nit: since we invoke python anyway, I'd rather do the math in Python as well

mmm, wait, why -ge in the last part? I think you need -lt?

Python version in CentOS 8 is 3.6.8, so this is not applied.
Anyway, we can exclude pip from the upgrade process, or impose a specific version, which is not a bad idea in terms of consistency considering that we're using virtualenvs everywhere.
If we only upgrade pip, the jobs where python is 3.6.9 or higher will fail, that's why I'm upgrading setuptools and wheels; we could also specify a version for these packages and stick with that.

Wait, this shouldn't be happening. What exactly cannot we do with new Python? What you have means that we update pip, setuptools and wheels unconditionally on CentOS 8, which is something I'm trying to avoid. At the very least, we only upgrade pip right now, and it seems to work.
3.6.10 on my Fedora bundles pip 19.1.1 and it seems to work. CentOS 8 has 9.0.3, which works as well. I've pulled a bionic container, and it seems to have 9.0.1 which supports -c.

deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-base.yaml.message: Does hardcoding this have any negative effect downstream?

Yep, John/Giulio, do you think we can just abandon this idea or we can create a tht variable and then get_parameter here?
I'm not totally sure what is the best way to proceed.

I think we totally agree for the downstream-only change.
Not sure about where is better to have this repo hardcoded, at least tripleo-validations seems a good place because this value is already hardcoded there and we can simply change it to a valid upstream value.
However I'm wondering if we want to control this value here: in this case a tht parameter should be a good way to do it.
I'm going to update this review adding the tht parameter, let's keep the discussion open and then we can choose to move forward with this patch.

Agree w/ you, this could generate issues downstream since the repo is different.
Talking about upstream, if we don't specify this variable here, we rely on this default [1], and this let the playbook fail, so I'm not sure if the best move is to set the tripleo ceph nautilus repo or avoiding this variable here.

+John +Giulio wdyt, should we consider abandoning this change?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations/src/branch/master/roles/ceph/defaults/main.yml#L6

The motivation for the repo validation was to ensure downstream users were getting the package from the right place. It was too easy to get it form the wrong place.

So there's already going to be a down-stream-only patch to line this up with the correct repos. 

Upstream I think it's fine to merge this as is. That's where tripleo will get it from.

I don't want to slow things down but if so, then maybe we can use a default in tripleo-validations, where it seems to fit best? and change that value only, downstream?

if we really want to control it from tht instead, which might make sense in case people is using local repos, then maybe we need a tht parameter?
maybe we want the | here , not sure how this looks without it

wait, this might be wrong

I think this should be 'centos-ceph-nautilus' by default, as per [1] and customize this value to 'tripleo-centos-ceph-nautilus' for the ci runs?

1. https://github.com/CentOS-Storage-SIG/centos-release-ceph/blob/nautilus/CentOS-Ceph-Nautilus.repo#L6

Not sure about the default here. In [1] we have centos-ceph-nautilus, and that's the value used if nothing here is provided (w/o this patch).
We can add here the same default of course, and then customize the CI to use "tripleo-centos-ceph-nautilus" value, I'm just not sure about the amount of deployments we need to change if we rely on "centos-ceph-nautilus" default instead of tripleo-centos-ceph-nautilus.

Maybe +fultonj can give an input here.


[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations/src/branch/master/roles/ceph/defaults/main.yml#L6

tripleo-centos-ceph-nautils is set created by tripleo-quickstart, I think, to replace the centos mirrors with a pointer to a local mirror; in tht though we should default to the standard upstream centos repo name which is centos-ceph-nautilus like seen in tripleo-validations

So, adding an equivalent for the checks API might make everything much more complex. If you OK with the rest, we could find a solution for that in a follow-up change.

tests/unit/test_github_driver.py.message: That's kind of a stupid test, but as the GithubReporter currently doesn't return anything (which would identify an error), I don't have any idea on how to check that the report failed because of missing app authentication. This test shows at least that the reporter and/or zuul doesn't crash on this :-)

zuul/driver/github/githubconnection.py.message: Checks api is exclusively for apps so this will break gating on all deployments that use api token auth.
This must be guarded based on the auth method as the checks api is unavailable for non-apps.

Current deployments probably need the documented additional access rights to access checks. So we need to prepare ourselves that this might fail with 401 and handle this gracefully. This is needed for a proper upgrade path as it's necessary to not just update the permissions of the app but the users of the app must acknowledge the new permissions.
We need to guard this as well against permission denied.

I'm a bit concerned about changing the API here.  It's currently a static method, and this changes it to a regular method, which means that Class.get_os_codename_package(...) will break in other charms.

I've made a suggestion that the default release selector already has the information that this needs (self.package_codenames and self.release_pkg) and it could pass it to this function.

Ok, you're right, I guess I got ahead of myself in changing the world ;) Thank you!

I will keep the change from Exception -> ValueError though, that should be 100% compatible as ValueError descends from Exception [0].

In this case it's setting diskimage-builder options which have to be omitted if not set because setting it to '' or None causes build failures. like:

  - set_fact:

      vars:

          'DIB_LOCAL_IMAGE': '{{ tripleo_overcloud_image_build_dib_local_image }}'
          'STABLE_BRANCH': '{{ tripleo_overcloud_image_build_stable_branch }}'
      when: item.value

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message: This should be updated for locked, right?

It looks like you're copying 'cleaned' here but that doesn't seem right, and you might just be getting lucky in tests because sqlite mght be treating 1 and 0 as true/false, but cleaned is an integer column and locked is a boolean. So really you should be using whatever underlying bool the db engine uses.

I think you could either just include 'locked' in the exact_match_filter_names list below, otherwise you'd need to do something like:

filter_val = true if locked else false  # from sqla imports
query_prefix = query_prefix.filter_by(locked=filter_val())

Note that filter_by might not work here, you might need to use query_prefix.filter() - see how false() and true() are used elsewhere in here.

_exact_instance_filter might be able to handle an exact match with a boolean, at least for sqlite and mysql, I'm not sure about other databases like postgresql though (I know DB2 stores booleans as 1 and 0 values but we don't support DB2 anymore).

Looking at other boolean columns on the instances table, shutdown_terminate and auto_disk_config are booleans but not handled in this query/filtering method so I guess we can't tell what they do (they are just ignored I guess).

hmm I had tested this with devstack and it worked so I guess I didn't give it much thought, but maybe for non-mysql it might not work, I'll just add this to the exact_match_filter_names like you have suggested and see.

I think I mentioned this before, but the locked boolean filter might be working here, but some RDBMS store booleans as 0 and 1, so technically we maybe should be checking isinstance(value, bool) and then filter using sqlalchemy.true()/false().

Having said that, mysql [1] and postgresql [2] should be fine with this, although mysql is a bit funky - but based on our usage it should be consistent.

Having said that, have you tested filtering servers by the locked param in a devstack (mysql) environment? Because the in-tree tests will be using sqlite and for sqlite it's a 0/1 value [3].

[1] http://www.mysqltutorial.org/mysql-boolean/
[2] https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.1/datatype-boolean.html
[3] https://www.sqlite.org/draft/datatype3.html

(later)

OK I see you said you tested this in devstack [4] so alright let's go with it. PostgreSQL should be OK as well but if not and there is a PG user out there that hits it and cares about this we can fix it. For other DBs like DB2 that might not work with this, oh well - they aren't supported upstream anyway.

[4] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/648662/8/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py@2151

tasks/collect.yml.message:
afaics this seems equivalent to what was happening before...

here you no longer do the rsync, instead directly do everything in /tmp and then move it to collect_dir

[EDIT]: well that isn't entirely true you are changing the behaviour. You no longer consider file size instead zip all the things. Perhaps worth calling that out in the commit message.
This risks running out of disk on remote machine, the only approach that I would find safe would be to use a `tar|gzip|ssh|ungzip` pipe, so we stream the data and never store it locally.

If there is so big risk of possible running out of disk, why the role copies all the logs to /tmp? their size is doubled .. if we can afford store the logs twice, i don't see a problem if we create another copy using tar as it will have only ~10% of the original size.
We never hit the situation with out of space on remote machine, during years of running it. This risk could be ignored.

I do find /tmp use as a bug which may need to be addressed too, but clearly not a valid excuse to double the disk requirements. If I remember well logs are copied with CoW or hardlinking to tmp, which should not increase disk space. Create a tar archive, does clearly need more space.


I started a POC for streaming the logs at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/708362/ and I am waiting for the CI results, local testing was quite positive. Also it is mandatory to use --fast with gzip or we will risk slowing down the process due to gzip taking too much CPU. Still the streaming approach works only for ssh connections and may need some tunning.

what is usual node capacity and how much space is used by average logs? I bet there is much more space available than the size of archive which is again, approx 10% of the original size.

Even if not ignored, put aside for sure. This discussions are pointlessly blocking the downstream initiative to reuse the role. So much to the big priority of reusing the tool.

distributedcloud/dcorch/engine/generic_s.message: I think this would be clearer if renamed to subcloud_state_matches()
The update_subcloud_state() could be called by multiple threads, is it thread-safe?
It could be called by multiple greenthreads (we are not using "real" threads). And yes - it is greenthread safe - it is just doing database updates, which are compatible with eventlet.

distributedcloud/dcorch/engine/initial_s.message: it shouldnt get here either if its current state is INITIAL_SYNC_STATE_COMPLETED
It won't get here because the if statement will return if the state is anything other than INITIAL_SYNC_STATE_FAILED.
Does this mean this thread will run forever if it has an exception in each loop? Would the dcmanager's subcloud state in initial state forever?

This thread runs forever by design. All it is doing is calling _initial_sync_subclouds, which creates a new greenthread for each subcloud that needs an initial sync. If one of those greenthreads raises an exception it is OK - we catch the exception in the thread and set the sync state to cause a retry.
No - if the reattempt fails it will come through this same code path and reattempt again.

distributedcloud/dcorch/engine/service.p.message: The update message from dcmanager seems to trigger an initial sync request for the subcloud by updating its initial sync state, and then the initial sync thread will check the state and start initial sync. I'm wondering how long does it take for the init sync thread to pick up the state? Is it depends on the TG timer interval? How long would the user wait to see the subcloud becomes managed?

The initial sync thread runs every 10s (SYNC_INTERVAL). However, each time the thread runs, it will launch all pending initial syncs and then wait for them to complete. This is by design, to throttle the number of initial syncs (currently limited to 50). So... if no initial syncs are currently in progress, the sync will start within 10s. If there are syncs in progress, we wait for them to complete (or fail) and then start the next batch in 10s.
Is it possible that the subcloud goes offline due to failed sync/authentication error and re-sync never attempted (as subcloud fails to go online)?
Would a failed audit trigger the subcloud to go offline while the initial sync is in progress or failed?

The initial sync will only be done for online subclouds (as it is before I made this change). The failure to do the initial sync should not prevent a subcloud from going online. Is there a reason that would happen?

Yes - a failed audit would cause the subcloud to go offline. If the initial sync is in progress, it will complete (unless connectivity is lost in which case it will fail). If the initial sync is failed, the retries are cancelled when the subcloud goes offline.

molecule/default/playbook.yml.message: I might be wrong here, but AFAIK the file module don't wipe the directory with state: directory

what is the significance of that notation please I've not encountered it before

No special notation, just a way to make it clear that there 
is more than one Converge, so if you grep for it, you can identify the correct one. I can easile use "Converge publish play".

Look 2 lines above, ansd youwill see artcl_publish, which is the documented way to use that code.  If you check README, you will fine in first paragraph that tasks_from counts as private interface and should not be used.

To explain in more detail:
a) ok to use tasks_from inside a role task files
b) really bad to use tasks_from to call role internals
c) probably-bad to use tasks_from in role tests, as it imposes risks of missing to test how is consumed. Still, there are corner-cases where it may make sense to do it, for example you want to test an additional execution path without having to re-run the entire role. Use of common-sense in that case.

tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/.message: I'd like to keep consistency with podman command arguments. Also it's all cpus by default
it'll take all cpus by default if not mentioning cpuset in options, no need to calculate it

see for example:

$ sudo podman run -it --rm --cpuset-cpus 1,2,3 alpine cat /sys/fs/cgroup/cpuset/cpuset.cpus
1-3
$ sudo podman run -it --rm --cpuset-cpus 1 alpine cat /sys/fs/cgroup/cpuset/cpuset.cpus
1
$ sudo podman run -it --rm  alpine cat /sys/fs/cgroup/cpuset/cpuset.cpus
0-3
so you always set cpuset-cpus and set it to all allowed CPUs, I'm not sure what is the use case here

I'm not sure it's good idea to calculate it in the module, it should be a 1:1 interface to podman, this will overload it.

Maybe better to calculate allowed CPUs in task before with taskset or psutil and then to set cpuset to this value when running this module

More detail clarification on what resources will be deleted automatically and how they will be determined is needed from user POV.

Another question: I don't think blazar can always treat all possible neutron use cases. What happens if blazar cannot a network with a reservation for example because there are new neutron resources which blazar does not know?

If there is a new type of resources unknown to Blazar associated with Neutron networks, deleting the network would fail, right? I would propose that if Blazar fails to delete the Neutron network, the associated network segment is marked as not reservable to prevent other reservations from using it. Currently, blazar will delete router and subnets associated with the reserved network. This is something user should be aware of before using reserve-able network resources.

I am okay with it. openstack_auth has no dependency on horizon now. Hopefully we can propose it to mock itself :)
Could you use same name as mocked methods as mock_xxx arguments? It is nice from POV of the code readability.
Can't we use helpers.create_mocks() here and other places?

I am against the comment.

As of now, openstack_auth module has no dependencies on horizon. Some modules in horizon import openstack_auth, so I don't think it is a good idea to introduce dependencies potentially circulated.

In addition, create_mocks() was introduced to minimize the diff from create_mox() when dropping mox usage. mock.patch is already simple enough and common in OpenStack projects, so I don't think we need to introduce it in a module which does not use it.
I still think it is better to do similar changes for mock arguments corresponding to "get_access" ("mock_token" and "mock_access". It is my personal preference, so we can clean up them later.
